_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary 



OXARC, Inc.

1901 N. Bingham Dr.

Nampa, ID 83651



Process: Storage of Chlorine and Ammonia Ton-Containers and 150 Pound Cylinders

    

1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

We are OXARC, Inc. are strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as receipt of containers and product, storage, and employee training associated with the chemicals at this facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. 



Under the Accidental Release Prevention Program, responsibility for the proper handling and storage of toxic gases stored at this facility is overseen by the facility manager and by the Safety and Compliance Manager. Additionally, OXARC, Inc. senior management have responsibility to ensure facility managers and compliance personnel keep the program up-to-date and that all reports and findings are taken care of in a timely manner.



2.    The Regulated Substances Handled

The facility is accessible to about six authorized employees and is secured during non-operational hours.  There are two substances at this facility above the threshold quantity: ammonia (anhydrous) and chlorine (separate, not in mixtures) in cylinders with capacities of 150 pounds and 2000 pounds. The estimated maximum amount of ammonia on hand is approximately 31,000 pounds total in the containers listed above. The maximum amount of chlorine on hand is approximately 30,000 pounds in the containers listed above. There are no filling processes performed of either chemical at this facility. Only processes associated with these substances are the storage, loading/unloading, and transportation in and out of this location.



3.    General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

This facility has taken all of the necessary steps to

comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at this facility.



Process Safety Information. OXARC, Inc. maintains safety information that describes the chemical hazards, handling, and storage of the regulated substance at this facility. All affected personnel are trained on hazmat handling.



Process Hazard Analysis. This facility conducts reviews to ensure that hazards associated with the handling, storage, and filling of cylinders are identified and controlled efficiently. Any findings related the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA review was performed on 11/29/19.



Operating Procedures. For the purpose of safely handling and storing cylinders, OXARC, Inc. has written procedures that address how to respond to accidental releases. In lieu of conducting any actual operations involving ammonia or chlorine, the EPA has assisted OXARC in determining that sufficient emergency response procedures would meet this requirement.



Training. OXARC, Inc. has a comprehensive program in place to ensure employees who are responsible for the handling of hazardous substances are competent in the procedures. Refresher training is provided on an ongoing basis.



Mechanical Integrity. OXARC, Inc. takes great care in ensuring that the structural integrity of the containers and cylinders is maintained throughout the handling and storage of these containers, cylinders, and any equipment associated with the process. Cylinders and ton containers at this facility are subject to the maintenance requirements of the US Department of Transportation and are required to be maintained by the container owner.



Management of Change. The most recent review/revision of procedures was performed on 1/31/19. Employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in the operating procedures are promptly

made aware of and trained in these changes. 



Compliance Audits. The resubmission of this RMP has prompted the facility to conduct a compliance audit. Performed on 1/31/2020.



Incident Investigation. OXARC, Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could result in an unintentional release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years. There has not been an incident at this facility.



Employee Participation. OXARC, Inc. believes that safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. OXARC employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of this facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from any hazard analyses. Employees are free to contact members of OXARC's executive team as they feel necessary.



Contractors. On occasion, OXARC, Inc. hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety of the contractor is carried out. OXARC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractors work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release occur. However, contractors are not involved with any process relating to the regulated chemicals nor are they authorized to enter chemical storage areas without pre-authorization from Oxarc's management team.



4.    Five-Year Accident History

There is no accident history to report.



5.    Emergency Response Plan

OXARC, Inc. has Emergency Response Procedures in place for employees to review. The plan identifies person

nel responsibilities and procedures for notifying the public and appropriate agencies. Addition information includes first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat accident human exposures as well are procedures for response following an accidental release of a regulated substance. 



Canyon County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee covering this facility.



6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

OXARC, Inc. has no plans at the present time.



HAZARD REVIEW



A hazard review was performed 11/29/19 for the storage of ammonia and chlorine.
